awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tracking Novel Metal Isotope Signatures during Subduction Metamorphism
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction is a key geologic process governing the Earth’s chemical evolution.  Through this process, sediments bearing the chemical signatures of low-temperature interaction with the hydrosphere and atmosphere are delivered, along with ocean crust altered by interaction with seawater, to the Earth’s deep interior.  With increasing depth and pressure, metamorphic changes to the subducting slab’s mineralogy lead to the release of fluids and, in some cases, melts, enriched in some elements over others.  These materials may return to the Earth’s surface via the route of arc volcanism, leaving behind a chemically altered slab that continues to sink deeper into the mantle.  The research broadly aims to better understand the chemical exchange that occurs between the slab and overlying mantle during subduction metamorphism using the molybdenum (Mo) and thallium (Tl) isotope tracer systems.  Isotopes of Mo and Tl experience strong fractionation in the oceans, leading to distinct isotope signatures in sediments and altered ocean crust that are ultimately transferred to subduction zones.  While recent research on the Mo and Tl isotope systems in volcanic arc rocks indicate that Tl isotopes match subduction zone inputs well, there is a large mismatch between the Mo isotope composition of most arcs and subduction zone inputs.  The work will focus on the origins of the divergent behaviors of the Mo and Tl isotope systems and provide new understanding of the deep Earth cycling of these elements. 
 
The work uses two well-characterized suites of high pressure-low temperature (HPLT) metamorphic rocks as analogs for the chemical processes and mineralogical changes that occur in sedimentary rocks during subduction.  The Schistes Lustres and related rocks from the western Alps exhibit a metamorphic gradient that ultimately reaches pressures approaching 3 GPa, but prior work has shown only limited mobile-element loss.  The Catalina Schist from California represents warmer subduction metamorphic conditions and shows considerable mobile element loss.  The bulk-rock Mo and Tl isotope compositions of the two sample suites will be determined in order to ascertain whether these isotope systems experience fractionation during HPLT metamorphism.  In situ analysis via LA-ICP-MS will determine which minerals host these elements and how they are redistributed during progressive metamorphism.  Isotope analysis of purified mineral splits will determine whether isotopic fractionation occurs between mineral phases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to use rock and mineral samples from two distinct and well-characterized subduction terranes to better understand how elements are recycled near Earth's surface. Subduction is a common Earth process that involves the collision of two tectonic plates with each other where one plate, usually the denser plate, is pushed, or subducted, underneath the other. Subduction is a fundamental way in which many materials, chiefly chemical elements, are recycled. During subduction, elements may be remobilized through one or a combination of processes, such as: 1) melting and releasing of elements from the plate as it subducts deeper into the earth and enters the mantle, where it may become difficult for the elements to return to the surface; 2) transportation of the melt, and the elements within, back to the surface, where it can be expelled via volcanic activity; and 3) interaction with various fluids, either released from the plate as water-bearing minerals break down or from fluids deep within the earth, which can either introduce or remove various elements from the plate. Knowing how these elements behave below the surface and whether they return to the surface through volcanism or stay below within the mantle is important for understanding how Earth has evolved over time, where new and existing metal deposits may be located, which are critical for our ongoing energy transition, and where and how higher concentrations of metals may pose an environmental or human health threat.

 

Here we focused on two sample suites from subduction zone environments, one from the Schistes Lustrés Complex in the Western Italian Alps and another from the Catalina Schist on Santa Catalina Island in California. The Schistes Lustrés is a suite of rocks that were part of a subduction zone that was brought back to the surface, or exhumed, which preserved key mineral phases of interest across the entire subducted path. This preservation allowed us to sample rocks and minerals, which are now on the surface, that represent various depths below the surface during previous subduction. Samples here were exposed to moderate to very high pressures (P) and variably high temperatures (T), characteristic of high-grade metamorphic conditions. As the rocks and their mineral assemblages were subjected to higher P-T conditions, various mineral phases became unstable and broke down, allowing new minerals to stabilize and form in their place, resulting in the redistribution of chemical elements during this process. The Catalina Schist is a more complicated area, which has been mechanically mixed and metasomatized, meaning it has been heavily altered by interacting with fluids of different chemical composition. This intense fluid alteration has resulted in distinct reaction rinds on many rocks in the region, leading to a very different chemistry on the outer edges of rocks that have interacted with those fluids as compared with the cores, or unaltered centers, of those same rocks. These reaction rinds allowed us to directly measure how interactions with fluids can impact element movement on both large and small scales.

 

This work used the chemical element thallium (Tl), including the two isotopes of Tl, 205Tl and 203Tl, as well as concentration data, as a tool to monitor how fluids might have interacted with the subducted plate. These fluids can cause the mobilization of elements, either through introduction or removal. Because Tl is a very fluid-mobile and redox sensitive element, it can track how various types of sediments may be involved in subduction and provide insight into how fluids behave during this process. This allows us to not only understand how fluids interact with subducting plates, but also how elemental mobilization occurs during subduction. We were able to use this element and these two sample suites to determine 1) that the minerals present during different stages of subduction strongly impact element retention or mobility, 2) some metals, such as Tl, should be fairly efficiently recycled back to the surface during subduction, and 3) interaction with fluids can greatly change the chemistry of rocks and complicate interpretations about what happened below the surface.

 

This project was conducted collaboratively by students and researchers at the University of Massachusetts Lowell and Indiana University (IU). Here at IU, the project served as the basis for an undergraduate honors thesis, six public presentations, and three published papers with two more in development. In addition, this project included a classroom visit to PI Rader’s alma mater, Estill County High School, and a virtual visit to a regional Upward Bound program, TRIO Upward Bound based in Indianapolis, to discuss the field of Earth Sciences and career paths within it from the perspective of a first-generation college graduate as well as a recorded YouTube video highlighting a day in the life of a trace metal geochemist, which has been used for multiple outreach events (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PyjABzw41Gk).
